review: I've been using the Amazon Fire TV box (about the size of double CD case) for a couple of weeks on my 1.5 Mb connection and it is phenomenal. I can stream tons of free content with no buffering, and the list of available apps/stations grows every day.You need a $100 per year Amazon Prime account to use the device, but the deal includes free 2-day shipping on all Amazon orders all year so I come out ahead. The box can also handle some games (controller sold separately); nothing a hard core gamer would get excited about, but OK for the rest of us.About the only downside I can see is that you can't expect HD images at the 1.5Mb speed, and you may need to pay fees or subscriptions to watch some things - especially sports. It generally takes weeks or months after release for movies to show up for free. If you can't wait you have to pay for it with a service like Netflix. It is also a little annoying that Amazon has chosen to lock up the home screen, making it difficult to customize it.I would recommend going with the box instead of the stick. The box has more memory and speed, and you can side load programs (like a browser) from a computer.Other than that, be prepared to change the way you watch TV. Devices like this make watching TV a much less passive activity. You need to make a list of the kind of stuff you like to watch, and then figure out what apps to load to get it (hopefully for free). Then, rather than sitting there surfing through hundreds of garbage channels for something/anything to watch, you will have to choose between thousands of programs you actually want to watch - and when you want to watch them. That's harder than you might think.
author: Amazon Customer
